title: 110_hr2740
content: The Act may be cited as the "MEJA Expansion and Enforcement Act of 2007". It addresses the legal status of contract personnel. The Military Extraterritorial Jurisdiction Act is amended to include contractors employed under US government contracts in areas where the Armed Forces is conducting a contingency operation. This expands the legal definition of personnel covered under the Act. The Military Extraterritorial Jurisdiction Act is amended to include contractors employed under US government contracts in areas where the Armed Forces is conducting a contingency operation. The Department of Justice Inspector General is required to submit a report to Congress within 180 days on investigations of alleged violations of section 3261 of title 18, United States Code, by contract personnel. The Department of Justice conducts investigations and opens criminal cases, with findings and recommendations on cases involving violations of section 3261 of title 18, United States Code. The report also includes information on charges brought against contractors working in Iraq or Afghanistan under covered contracts. The report includes a list of charges against contractors or contract personnel working under covered contracts in Iraq or Afghanistan, detailing the offenses and outcomes. It also describes any legal actions taken by the United States Government in response to criminal charges against contractors or contract personnel. The report under paragraph (1) includes a list of charges against contractors or contract personnel in Iraq or Afghanistan, detailing offenses and outcomes. It may contain a classified annex if necessary. SEC. 3. FEDERAL BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION INVESTIGATIVE UNIT FOR CONTINGENCY OPERATIONS. Establishment of Theater Investigative Unit to investigate criminal violations by contract personnel in theater of operations, including reports of misconduct, fatalities from unlawful force, and referral of cases to the Attorney General for further action. The Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation is responsible for ensuring each Theater Investigative Unit has adequate resources and personnel. They must notify Congress of any establishment or termination of a Unit and can request security assistance from the Secretary of Defense if needed. The Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation can request security assistance for a Theater Investigative Unit from the Secretary of Defense. The Attorney General can also request assistance from other Executive agencies for the Unit. The Director must provide an annual report on compliance with the Act. The Director of the FBI must submit a report to Congress detailing reports received by Theater Investigative Units on criminal misconduct and fatalities involving contractors, cases referred for further investigation, and recommended changes to Federal law. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, a "covered contract" refers to a prime contract, subcontract, or task order carried out outside the US during a contingency operation by an agency as defined in section 105 of title 5, United States Code. The terms defined in this section include "Executive agency," "contingency operation," "contractor," and "contract personnel." The provisions of this Act apply to covered contracts and personnel in areas where the Armed Forces are conducting a contingency operation. The Act goes into effect immediately upon enactment and agencies have 90 days to ensure compliance. SEC. 6. RULE OF CONSTRUCTION. This Act does not impact intelligence activities allowed before its enactment.
